title: Why pick Garen over Darius?
body:

replies.body:
Garen is a beginner champion meant for low-elo. He takes almost no skill whatsoever, so he's great for introducing people to Juggernaunts. 

He's terrible in higher elo because they know how to kite, and Garen is useless when the enemy is competent enough to kite and CC him.

He's not meant to be played in high elo. If a simple champion like Garen or Amumu is being played in ~~high elo~~ the LCS, they are supremely overpowered and need nerfs.

Darius is the higher-elo Juggernaut. He's meant to be what the beginners move up to when they learn the basics of their duty as a Juggernaut.

So, there is NO reason to pick Garen over Darius. Unless you're really, REALLY good at him. Even then, it would be better to learn Darius.

Though to be fair, Darius's weakness is also kiting and CC, but he has more answers to that other than just running at the enemy and hoping he hits them.
If garen requires no skill, then why are there hardstuck bronze and silver Garen mains and there are high diamond Garen mains

This is a bit off topic, but champions like Garen provide a really interesting look at the difference in balancing philosophies between League and Dota2.

In League they try and balance the game for all elos, which means that obviously some champions suffer. For example, Garen works in Bronze but never Challenger. 

In Dota2 all champions are balanced around the highest levels of play. So pretty much everything is at least situationally viable. The upside is that pro matches and games are much more exciting, dynamic, and offer far more variety than League could ever hope to have. The downside is that in low elo certain champs dominate.

Should League do the same, I imagine pro game viewership would skyrocket, and Bronze would be full of 60%+ winrate Garens. And when they inevitably complain, the answer is basically "git gud."

I'll give the legitimate reason other than the dumb "he's an easier champion" argument. I play Garen over Darius because Garen can split push more effectively and if he gets the right flank on the villain, can quickly kill them in a teamfight, swinging the favor immediately into your team's favor. Garen has faster waveclear mid game and self speed buff to push side lanes and roam better. In teamfights, obviously Darius has an easier time running head first and getting multi-person Q's while using two types of CC. You can't play Garen like Darius. You try to flank and go for vulnerable targets/villain. Once you assassinate the villain, you either clean up the fight by going for the next villain or go split push with passive HP regen. 

In conclusion: {{champion:122}}  brute force teamfights and shit. {{champion:86}}  splits, roams, assasinate (have access to single target true damage nuke without prep) villains. Granted, Darius can do all of these things, but Garen is more well-rounded.
Because Garen is very fun, regardless of how useless he may be in most scenarios. Also, there really anything more satisfying than ulting the villain.

Although Darius is essentially a better version of Garen, Garen is more accessible to new players. He doesn't require as much mechanical skill, and even has a passive that encourages csing.

So, why pick Garen over Darius?
To learn the fundamentals of the Juggernaut class with a straight-forward, easy to learn champ.

I was just trying to answer some of the questions originally posed by your previous comment. I presented another's arguments while not necessarily supporting them.

Darius fits the same slot as Garen, yes, but he literally does not provide everything Garen can provide. Namely, armor shred and flat damage reduction. Garen is tankier, and his sustain is better at sieging. If you have a heavy AD team, he also brings teamfight utility beyond personal damage.

I'd agree that Darius is generally better than Garen in that slot, but he isn't a strictly better version of the character. 

> And im sorry, but Darius does provide all of the thing garen does but better

This is incorrect. See flat damage reduction and armor shred. Since Darius does not do these things, he, by definition, _does not_  provide all of the things Garen does. Generally, people will like the higher damage output and teamfight sustain that Darius brings, and prefer Darius as their bruiser top laner over Garen, but that _does not mean_  that he is a better verion of Garen. Similar, but different.
